@metadata.goal: The student can recognize and identify equal versus unequal parts

steps.dialogue: This bar is divided into eighths. Look closely at each section.

prompt.text: Is this bar divided into equal parts?

step.dialogue: Look more closely at the size of each section.

events.name: pulse_unequal_sections
events.description: The smallest and largest sections pulse alternately to highlight size differences

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_unequal_sections]Let's think about this together. For parts to be equal, they all need to be exactly the same size. Compare the sections carefully.

events.name: measure_sections_unequal
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines appearing above each section sequentially, with width labels highlighting the size differences between sections

step.dialogue: [event:measure_sections_unequal]This can be tricky, so let's work through it together. Watch as we measure each section. See how some sections are wider than others? That means they're not equal. For eighths to be equal, all 8 parts must be exactly the same size. That's why the answer is no.

on_correct.dialogue: You analyzed carefully and identified the unequal parts.

@metadata.goal: The student can recognize and identify equal versus unequal parts

steps.dialogue: Marcus divided a rectangle into sixths. Look closely at each part—are they all the same size?

prompt.text: Is this bar divided into equal parts?

step.dialogue: Look closely at each section. Are they all exactly the same size?

events.name: pulse_unequal_section
events.description: The smallest and largest sections pulse alternately to highlight the size difference

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_unequal_section]Let's think about this together. For parts to be equal, they all need to be the same size. Look at each section carefully.

events.name: measure_sections_unequal
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines highlighting the size differences between the smallest and largest sections

events.name: outline_smallest_and_largest
events.description: The smallest section is outlined in one color and the largest in another, then a comparison animation shows them side by side

step.dialogue: [event:measure_sections_unequal][event:outline_smallest_and_largest]This can be tricky, so let's work through it together. Watch as we compare the sections. See how this section is smaller than this one? When parts are different sizes, they're unequal. That's why the answer is No—these parts aren't all the same size.

@metadata.goal: The student can identify and maintain the whole when working with fractions

steps.dialogue: Two friends each have a paper strip. Both strips are divided into parts, and some parts are shaded. Do both wholes have the same number of equal parts?

step.dialogue: Not quite. Count the total parts in each whole strip.

events.name: pulse_all_sections_top
events.description: All four sections of top bar pulse together to show total parts

events.name: pulse_all_sections_bottom
events.description: All four sections of bottom bar pulse together to show total parts

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_all_sections_top][event:pulse_all_sections_bottom]Let's think about this together. The shading doesn't change how many parts each whole has. Count all the parts in each strip.

events.name: count_sections_sequentially_top
events.description: Each section of top bar highlights in sequence with counting overlay: 1, 2, 3, 4

events.name: count_sections_sequentially_bottom
events.description: Each section of bottom bar highlights in sequence with counting overlay: 1, 2, 3, 4

events.name: fade_shading_top
events.description: Shading temporarily fades to show all parts are equal regardless of shading

events.name: fade_shading_bottom
events.description: Shading temporarily fades to show all parts are equal regardless of shading

step.dialogue: [event:count_sections_sequentially_top][event:count_sections_sequentially_bottom][event:fade_shading_top][event:fade_shading_bottom]This can be tricky, so let's work through it together. The top strip has 4 equal parts total. The bottom strip also has 4 equal parts total. The shading tells us how much is used, but both wholes are divided the same way. That's how we know both wholes have the same number of equal parts.

on_correct.dialogue: You compared the wholes and saw both have four equal parts.

@metadata.goal: The student can compare sizes of unit fractions

steps.dialogue: These bars show parts of ribbons used for crafts. Which bar has the bigger shaded part?

prompt.text: Select the bar with the bigger shaded part

step.dialogue: Not quite. Compare the size of one shaded piece in each bar.

events.name: outline_shaded_piece_bar_sixths
events.description: The shaded piece in bar_sixths is outlined to draw attention

events.name: outline_shaded_piece_bar_eighths
events.description: The shaded piece in bar_eighths is outlined to draw attention

step.dialogue: [event:outline_shaded_piece_bar_sixths][event:outline_shaded_piece_bar_eighths]Let's think about this together. When a bar is divided into more pieces, each piece gets smaller. Compare the shaded pieces carefully.

events.name: extract_and_enlarge_piece_bar_sixths
events.description: The shaded piece from bar_sixths is extracted and enlarged for comparison

events.name: extract_and_enlarge_piece_bar_eighths
events.description: The shaded piece from bar_eighths is extracted and enlarged, positioned next to the sixth piece to show size difference

events.name: pulse_correct_answer
events.description: Bar_sixths pulses to indicate it is the correct answer

step.dialogue: [event:extract_and_enlarge_piece_bar_sixths][event:extract_and_enlarge_piece_bar_eighths][event:pulse_correct_answer]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. The top bar has 6 equal parts, so each piece is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction]. The bottom bar has 8 equal parts, so each piece is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=8]one eighth[/fraction]. When we divide into more parts, each piece gets smaller. So [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction] is bigger than [fraction numerator=1 denominator=8]one eighth[/fraction]. That's why fewer parts means bigger pieces.

on_correct.dialogue: You compared the unit fractions and found the larger piece.

@metadata.goal: The student can compare sizes of unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Two cakes are cut into equal parts for parties. Which cake gives each person a bigger piece?

prompt.text: Select the bar where each person gets the biggest piece

step.dialogue: Not quite. Think about which cake is cut into fewer pieces.

events.name: highlight_single_section
events.description: One section from the top bar is outlined and pulses

events.name: highlight_single_section_bottom
events.description: One section from the bottom bar is outlined and pulses

step.dialogue: [event:highlight_single_section][event:highlight_single_section_bottom]Let's think about this together. When you cut something into fewer pieces, each piece is bigger. Compare one piece from each bar.

events.name: overlay_single_piece_extraction
events.description: One piece from the top bar is extracted and enlarged to show its size

events.name: overlay_single_piece_extraction_bottom
events.description: One piece from the bottom bar is extracted and enlarged, positioned next to the top bar piece for direct size comparison

events.name: pulse_correct_answer
events.description: The top bar pulses with a green glow to indicate it is the correct answer

step.dialogue: [event:overlay_single_piece_extraction][event:overlay_single_piece_extraction_bottom][event:pulse_correct_answer]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. The top bar is divided into 4 equal pieces, and the bottom bar is divided into 8 equal pieces. When we cut the same-sized cake into fewer pieces, each piece is bigger. So the top bar, with only 4 pieces, gives each person a bigger piece than the bottom bar with 8 pieces. That's how fractions work - fewer parts means bigger pieces.

on_correct.dialogue: You identified that fewer parts means bigger pieces.

@metadata.goal: The student can compare sizes of unit fractions

steps.dialogue: These bars show equal parts of the whole. Which bar has the smallest shaded part?

prompt.text: Select the bar with the smallest shaded part

step.dialogue: Look closely at the size of each shaded piece.

events.name: outline_shaded_piece_fourths
events.description: The shaded piece in bar_fourths is outlined to show its size

events.name: outline_shaded_piece_sixths
events.description: The shaded piece in bar_sixths is outlined to show its size for comparison

step.dialogue: [event:outline_shaded_piece_fourths][event:outline_shaded_piece_sixths]Let's think about this together. When a whole is divided into more parts, each part gets smaller. Compare the shaded pieces carefully.

events.name: measure_shaded_width_fourths
events.description: Animated measurement line appears showing the width of the shaded piece in bar_fourths

events.name: measure_shaded_width_sixths
events.description: Animated measurement line appears showing the width of the shaded piece in bar_sixths, demonstrating it is narrower

events.name: pulse_correct_answer
events.description: Bar_sixths pulses to indicate it has the smallest shaded part

step.dialogue: [event:measure_shaded_width_fourths][event:measure_shaded_width_sixths][event:pulse_correct_answer]This can be tricky, so let's work through it together. This bar has 4 equal parts, so each piece is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction]. This bar has 6 equal parts, so each piece is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction]. When we divide the same whole into more parts, each part becomes smaller. So [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction] is smaller than [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction]. That's why more parts means smaller pieces.

on_correct.dialogue: You identified that [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction] is smaller than [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction].

@metadata.goal: The student can compare sizes of unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Two groups are sharing chocolate bars. Each bar is divided equally among the group. Which bar gives each person the biggest piece?

prompt.text: Select the bar with the biggest pieces

step.dialogue: Not quite. Compare the size of one piece from each bar.

events.name: outline_single_piece
events.description: One section from each bar is outlined to show its size

step.dialogue: [event:outline_single_piece]Let's think about this together. When you divide the same size bar into more pieces, each piece gets smaller. Look at one piece from each bar.

events.name: overlay_single_piece_comparison
events.description: One piece from top bar is highlighted and labeled '1/2', one piece from bottom bar is highlighted and labeled '1/8', showing it is smaller

events.name: pulse_correct_answer
events.description: Top bar pulses to indicate it has the bigger pieces

step.dialogue: [event:overlay_single_piece_comparison][event:pulse_correct_answer]This can be tricky, so let's work through it together. Both bars start the same size. The top bar is divided into 2 pieces, so each piece is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=2]one half[/fraction]. The bottom bar is divided into 8 pieces, so each piece is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=8]one eighth[/fraction]. When we divide into fewer pieces, each piece is bigger. That's how halves are bigger than eighths.

on_correct.dialogue: You identified that halves are bigger than eighths.

@metadata.goal: The student can compare sizes of unit fractions

steps.dialogue: These bars show unit fractions with different denominators. Which bar has the smallest shaded part?

prompt.text: Click on the bar with the smallest shaded part

step.dialogue: Not quite. Compare the size of one shaded piece in each bar.

events.name: outline_single_piece
events.description: The first shaded piece of both bars is outlined to highlight the comparison

step.dialogue: [event:outline_single_piece]Let's think about this together. When a bar is divided into more pieces, each piece gets smaller. Look at how many pieces each bar has.

events.name: overlay_piece_comparison
events.description: Animated overlay extracts the shaded pieces from both bars and displays them side by side, showing the sixths piece is smaller than the thirds piece

step.dialogue: [event:overlay_piece_comparison]This can be tricky, so let's work through it together. The bar with thirds has 3 equal pieces, and the bar with sixths has 6 equal pieces. When we divide the same-sized bar into more pieces, each piece becomes smaller. So [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction] is smaller than [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction]. That's why the bar with sixths has the smallest shaded part.

on_correct.dialogue: You compared the unit fractions and found the smallest piece.

@metadata.goal: The student can compare sizes of unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Two brownies are cut into equal parts. Each has one piece shaded. Which brownie has the bigger shaded piece?

prompt.text: Select the bar with the bigger shaded part

step.dialogue: Not quite. Compare the size of one shaded piece in each brownie.

events.name: outline_shaded_piece
events.description: Outline appears around the shaded pieces in both bars for comparison

step.dialogue: [event:outline_shaded_piece]Let's think about this together. When a brownie is cut into fewer pieces, each piece is bigger. Look at the shaded pieces.

events.name: extract_and_enlarge_shaded
events.description: The shaded pieces from both bars are extracted and enlarged for direct size comparison

events.name: highlight_correct_answer
events.description: The bar with halves pulses to indicate it is the correct answer with the bigger shaded piece

step.dialogue: [event:extract_and_enlarge_shaded][event:highlight_correct_answer]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. The top brownie is cut into 2 equal pieces - each piece is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=2]one half[/fraction]. The bottom brownie is cut into 4 equal pieces - each piece is [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction]. [fraction numerator=1 denominator=2]One half[/fraction] is bigger than [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction] because fewer cuts make bigger pieces. That's how unit fractions work - fewer equal parts means each part is larger.

on_correct.dialogue: You identified that fewer equal parts means bigger pieces.

@metadata.goal: The student can understand that all parts must be equal for unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Mia divided her ribbon into 6 parts and shaded one. Take a look at the parts she created.

prompt.text: Why doesn't the shaded part equal [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction]?

step.dialogue: Not quite. Look closely at the size of each part in the ribbon.

events.name: pulse_smallest_largest
events.description: The smallest and largest sections pulse alternately to highlight the size difference

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_smallest_largest]Let's think about this together. For a fraction to work, what needs to be true about all the parts? Look at the sections carefully.

events.name: measure_sections_unequal
events.description: Animated measurement lines appear above each section, showing different heights to demonstrate unequal sizes

events.name: highlight_size_differences
events.description: Color gradient overlay appears showing smallest sections in one color and largest in another, making inequality visible

step.dialogue: [event:measure_sections_unequal][event:highlight_size_differences]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. For something to be [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction], we need 6 equal parts. Look at Mia's ribbon - some sections are bigger and some are smaller. The parts aren't equal, so the shaded part can't be [fraction numerator=1 denominator=6]one sixth[/fraction]. That's why all parts need to be the same size for fractions.

on_correct.dialogue: You identified that unequal parts can't represent a fraction.

@metadata.goal: The student can understand that all parts must be equal for unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Here's a paper strip divided into 8 parts with one shaded. Can we call that shaded part [fraction numerator=1 denominator=8]one eighth[/fraction]?

prompt.text: Select whether the shaded part is 1/8

options: Yes, it's 1/8 because there are 8 parts
No, it's not 1/8 because the parts aren't equal

step.dialogue: Not quite. Look closely at the size of each part in the strip.

events.name: highlight_size_differences
events.description: The smallest and largest sections pulse alternately to show size differences between parts

step.dialogue: [event:highlight_size_differences]Let's think about this together. For a fraction to be [fraction numerator=1 denominator=8]one eighth[/fraction], all 8 parts need to be the same size. Check if these parts are equal.

events.name: measure_sections_unequal
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines highlighting the different widths of sections, with the smallest and largest sections labeled

events.name: show_equal_comparison
events.description: A semi-transparent overlay of what 8 equal parts would look like appears above the unequal bar for comparison

step.dialogue: [event:measure_sections_unequal][event:show_equal_comparison]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. For something to be [fraction numerator=1 denominator=8]one eighth[/fraction], we need 8 equal parts. Look at this strip - some parts are bigger and some are smaller. Since the parts aren't equal, we can't call any of them [fraction numerator=1 denominator=8]one eighth[/fraction]. All parts must be the same size for unit fractions.

on_correct.dialogue: You recognized that unequal parts can't make unit fractions.

@metadata.goal: The student can understand that all parts must be equal for unit fractions

steps.dialogue: Leo divided his poster into 4 sections and colored one. Can the colored part be called [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction]?

prompt.text: Select the reason why this isn't [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction]

options: Because the parts are not equal
Because the shaded part is too small

step.dialogue: Not quite. Look closely at the size of each section.

events.name: pulse_unequal_sections
events.description: Each section of bar_1 pulses sequentially to show size differences between parts

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_unequal_sections]Let's think about this together. For a fraction to work, all the parts need to be the same size. Look at these sections.

events.name: measure_sections_unequal
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines highlighting size differences between sections, with smallest and largest sections pulsing

events.name: overlay_smallest_over_largest
events.description: Outline of smallest section appears and animates over the largest section to demonstrate inequality

step.dialogue: [event:measure_sections_unequal][event:overlay_smallest_over_largest]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. For something to be [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction], we need 4 equal parts. Look at Leo's poster - the sections are different sizes. Some are bigger, some are smaller. Since the parts aren't equal, we can't call any of them [fraction numerator=1 denominator=4]one fourth[/fraction]. That's why the answer is 'Because the parts are not equal.' See how all parts need to be the same size for fractions.

on_correct.dialogue: You identified that fractions require equal parts.

@metadata.goal: The student can understand that all parts must be equal for unit fractions

steps.dialogue: This bar has three parts with one shaded. The denominator is 3, but something's not right about calling this [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction].

prompt.text: Select the part that breaks the fraction rule

step.dialogue: Check which parts are different sizes.

events.name: pulse_unequal_sections
events.description: The smallest and largest sections pulse alternately to draw attention to the size difference

step.dialogue: [event:pulse_unequal_sections]Let's think about this together. For a fraction to work, all parts must be equal. Look at the sizes of these three sections.

events.name: measure_sections_unequal
events.description: Animated overlay showing measurement lines highlighting the size differences between the smallest and largest sections

events.name: overlay_size_comparison
events.description: Visual comparison showing the smallest section overlaid on the largest section to demonstrate they are not equal

step.dialogue: [event:measure_sections_unequal][event:overlay_size_comparison]This is tricky, so let's work through it together. For [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction] to be accurate, all three parts need to be the same size. But look - this section is much smaller than this one. When parts aren't equal, we can't use fraction notation. That's why either the smallest or largest section shows the problem.

on_correct.dialogue: You found it - the parts aren't equal, so we can't call it [fraction numerator=1 denominator=3]one third[/fraction].
